awd_titl_txt: Exploring the Influence of Frustration near Quantum Criticality through Uniaxial Pressure
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical Abstract:

Dozens of strongly correlated materials exhibit similar but by no means identical behavior patterns. Classifying the behaviors and the conditions under which they occur has been a high priority for more than two decades, and it may prove key to eventually fabricating useful materials including room-temperature superconductors. This project explores the role of magnetic frustration, where a system favors local magnetic configurations which are not mutually compatible. The system must satisfy some local constraints but not others, leading to a large number of states with the same or very similar energy. Squeezing a sample along a single direction can shift the energy levels to a broader range, thereby reducing the influence of frustration on the sample's behavior. This project applies such unidirectional pressure and measures how it changes a sample's low-temperature electrical and magnetic behavior. Understanding the effects of frustration may help in designing materials with specific desired properties in the future. The specialized cooling and pressure techniques provide excellent training for the graduate and undergraduate students who perform the experiments.


Technical Abstract:

A major question in the low-temperature behavior of Yb-based heavy-fermion compounds is whether Kondo breakdown occurs, with a discontinuous jump in the size of the Fermi surface. More generally, the role of geometrical effects, such as geometic frustration and crystal dimensionality, should be ascertained. Uniaxial pressure is a natural technique for this purpose, since it affects both frustration and dimensionality more strongly than does hydrostatic pressure. This research involves specific heat, magnetic susceptibility, and transport measurements under uniaxial pressure up to 1 GPa, temperatures down to 30 mK, and magnetic fields up to 10 Tesla. These measurements establish a pressure-temperature-field phase diagram which reveals the importance of geometry among many competing influences. Of special note is the behavior of T*, the onset temperature for hybridization between the conduction electrons and local moments, under uniaxial pressure. T* is surprisingly stable to the related tuning techniques of hydrostatic pressure and chemical doping. One of the goals of this proposal is to test if the stability of the T* line occurs for uniaxial pressure as well.

por.por_cntn:
Electrons within different crystalline materials can produce astonishingly different behaviors. One example is the interaction between electrons and local magnetic moments within a material. Sometimes the electrons mediate an interaction between the moments, which can lead to magnetic order. In other cases, the electrons "screen" a moment, partially cancelling it so that at distant locations it appears much weaker than it actually is. This apparent weakening of the moments reduces their interaction and prevents magnetic order. Understanding these different interactions is particularly important because electron-moment interactions play a key role in many high-temperature superconductors.

One of the difficulties in sorting out the interactions is that materials which exhibit different electron-moment interactions may also differ in many other ways. Applying pressure to a single sample turns out to be a useful approach, since changing the spacing between the magnetic moments can alter the balance between the electron-moment interactions while miminizing other changes. Nonetheless, given the large number of materials-specific idiosyncracies, observing commonalities across many different compounds is key to identifying general patterns.

This award allowed measurements on several materials under pressure. Two of these compounds showed magnetic transitions under pressure. Illustrating how materials vary, in one case the magnetic change was accompanied by a change in the crystal structure, while in the other it was not. Other measurements explored the screening of moments by electrons as described above, and how pressure alters the strength of these moments. In one case, a compound thought to be an exception to general trends was found to follow the common behavior after all. Overall, additional materials were added to the present understanding of these effects and a few good candidates for future study were identified.

These low-temperature experiments are excellent training for many careers in science and technology. Several graduate students and undergraduates were involved over the course of the project. Thus one graduate student finished his Ph.D. and now has a permanent research position at a national laboratory, while another plans a programming or data science career. Two of the undergraduates are now enrolled in graduate programs.
